	      </p>
	      <p xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">
		<ref:anchor id="para_154" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		<text><ref:page num="105" page-scheme="7490" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> <ref:page num="P134" page-scheme="3481" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> In addition, <lnci:cite ID="I493DDGK0K1MND13D0000400" normcite="WIS. STAT. 940.203" normprotocol="lexstat" ri.key="41558050030" status="valid" xmlns:lnci="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/citations/1/">
		    <lnci:stat>
		      <lnci:statinfo>
			<lnci:hier>
			  <lnci:hierlev label="section" num="940.203">
			    <lnci:hierlev label="subsection" num="2"/>
			  </lnci:hierlev>
			</lnci:hier>
		      </lnci:statinfo>
		      <lnci:statref normcite="_940.203(2)()">
			<lnci:standardname normpubcode="6684" value="Wis. Stat."/>
		      </lnci:statref>
		    </lnci:stat>
		    <lnci:metadata>
		      <lnci:precedent>
			<lnci:editletter ID="I493DDGK0K1MND2BG0000400" appliedby="machine" comment="Cited in dissenting opinion at" letter="j"/>
		      </lnci:precedent>
		    </lnci:metadata>
		    <lnci:content>
		      <linktemplate:linktemplate rel="http://services.lexisnexis.com/shared/linkrelations/CITE-REF" href="/shared/document/statutes-legislation/urn:contentItem:55B2-G480-004G-W318-00000-00" type="application/xhtml+xml" domain="services" xmlns:linktemplate="services.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/linktemplate/1/">
			<request xmlns="">
			  <parameters>
			    <parameter style="query" name="CITE-REF" fixed="#6684#116#000940#   203#"/>
			    <parameter style="query" name="cfi:anchoridref" fixed="_2"/>
			    <parameter style="query" name="cfi:contentclasscode" fixed="5"/>
			    <parameter style="query" name="cfi:normcite" fixed="Wis. Stat. � 940.203"/>
			    <parameter style="query" name="spanid" fixed="I56N5HD52N1R360DN0000400"/>
			    <parameter style="query" name="contentcomponentid" fixed="10989"/>
			    <parameter style="query" name="priceplan" fixed="subscriptions"/>
			  </parameters>
			  <linktext>Wis. Stat. � 940.203(2)</linktext>
			</request>
		      </linktemplate:linktemplate>
		    </lnci:content>
		  </lnci:cite> (1997-98) penalizes a person who threatens a judge. <rfc:reasonforciting rfctoken="I4F246TY0K1MND3X30000400" xmlns:rfc="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/legal/reason-for-citing/1/"><ref:anchor id="I4F246TY0K1MND3X30000400" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>To render the statute constitutional against a <lnci:cite ID="I494C77C0K1MND1220000400" loadable="1" normcite="U.S. CONST. AMEND. 1" normprotocol="lexstat" ri.key="11984088" status="valid" xmlns:lnci="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/citations/1/">
		      <lnci:constitution>
			<lnci:constinfo>
			  <lnci:hier>
			    <lnci:hierlev label="catchword" num="amend.">
			      <lnci:hierlev label="number" num="1"/>
			    </lnci:hierlev>
			  </lnci:hier>
			</lnci:constinfo>
			<lnci:constref normcite="amend._1">
			  <lnci:standardname normpubcode="7492" value="U.S. Const."/>
			</lnci:constref>
		      </lnci:constitution>
		      <lnci:metadata>
			<lnci:precedent>
			  <lnci:editletter ID="I494C77C0K1MND1SN0000400" appliedby="machine" comment="Cited in dissenting opinion at" letter="j"/>
			</lnci:precedent>
		      </lnci:metadata>
		      <lnci:content popname="1">
			<linktemplate:linktemplate rel="http://services.lexisnexis.com/shared/linkrelations/CITE-REF" href="/shared/contentstore/statutes-legislation" type="application/xhtml+xml" domain="services" xmlns:linktemplate="services.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/linktemplate/1/">
			  <request xmlns="">
			    <parameters>
			      <parameter style="query" name="CITE-REF" fixed="#7492#207#        1 #"/>
			      <parameter style="query" name="cfi:contentclasscode" fixed="38"/>
			      <parameter style="query" name="cfi:normcite" fixed="U.S. Const. AMEND. 1"/>
			      <parameter style="query" name="spanid" fixed="I56N5HD52N1R360DP0000400"/>
			      <parameter style="query" name="filters" fixed=""/>
			    </parameters>
			    <linktext>First Amendment</linktext>
			  </request>
			</linktemplate:linktemplate>
		      </lnci:content>
		    </lnci:cite> challenge, the court defined the threat in the statute to cover only "true threats" in order <ref:page num="824" page-scheme="4922" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> to render the statute constitutional. A jury is instructed regarding the definition of "true threat" so that the jury can decide whether the facts fall within the statute or the prosecution is barred by the <lnci:cite ID="I494C77C0K1MND14B0000400" loadable="1" normcite="U.S. CONST. AMEND. 1" normprotocol="lexstat" ri.key="11984088" status="valid" xmlns:lnci="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/citations/1/">
		      <lnci:constitution>
			<lnci:constinfo>
			  <lnci:hier>
			    <lnci:hierlev label="catchword" num="amend.">
			      <lnci:hierlev label="number" num="1"/>
			    </lnci:hierlev>
			  </lnci:hier>
			</lnci:constinfo>
			<lnci:constref normcite="amend._1">
			  <lnci:standardname normpubcode="7492" value="U.S. Const."/>
			</lnci:constref>
		      </lnci:constitution>
		      <lnci:metadata>
			<lnci:precedent>
			  <lnci:editletter ID="I494C77C0K1MND1SP0000400" appliedby="machine" comment="Cited in dissenting opinion at" letter="j"/>
			</lnci:precedent>
		      </lnci:metadata>
		      <lnci:content popname="1">
			<linktemplate:linktemplate rel="http://services.lexisnexis.com/shared/linkrelations/CITE-REF" href="/shared/contentstore/statutes-legislation" type="application/xhtml+xml" domain="services" xmlns:linktemplate="services.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/linktemplate/1/">
			  <request xmlns="">
			    <parameters>
			      <parameter style="query" name="CITE-REF" fixed="#7492#207#        1 #"/>
			      <parameter style="query" name="cfi:contentclasscode" fixed="38"/>
			      <parameter style="query" name="cfi:normcite" fixed="U.S. Const. AMEND. 1"/>
			      <parameter style="query" name="spanid" fixed="I56N5HD52N1R360DR0000400"/>
			      <parameter style="query" name="filters" fixed=""/>
			    </parameters>
			    <linktext>First Amendment</linktext>
			  </request>
			</linktemplate:linktemplate>
		      </lnci:content>
		    </lnci:cite>. <footnote>
		      <ref:anchor id="fn_fnote80" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		      <label alt-content="n80">80</label>
		      <bodytext>
			<p>
			  <ref:anchor id="fnpara_118" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			  <text><rfc:anchorcite lni="434B-YPP0-0039-43S1-00000-00" rfctokenref="I4F246TY0K1MND3X30000400" status="valid">
			      <ref:anchor id="I4F246TY0K1MND3WW0000400" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			      <lnci:cite ID="I493DDGK0K1MND13J0000400" normprotocol="lexsee" ri.key="26536938" status="valid" xmlns:lnci="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/citations/1/">
				<lnci:case>
				  <lnci:caseinfo>
				    <lnci:casename>
				      <lnci:party1 name="State"/>
				      <lnci:text txt="v."/>
				      <lnci:party2 name="Perkins"/>
				    </lnci:casename>
				  </lnci:caseinfo>
				  <lnci:caseref ID="I493DDGK0K1MND13K0000400">
				    <lnci:reporter normpubcode="23642" value="WI"/>
				    <lnci:ldi jumppage="46" kw="1327_2001_46*.46" page="46" pagesuffix="*" reporter="1327" volume="2001"/>
				    <lnci:volume num="2001"/>
				    <lnci:page num="46"/>
				  </lnci:caseref>
				  <lnci:caseref ID="I493DDGK0K1MND13N0000400">
				    <lnci:reporter normpubcode="111" value="Wis. 2d"/>
				    <lnci:ldi jumppage="141" kw="2005_243_141*.141" page="141" pagesuffix="*" reporter="2005" volume="243"/>
				    <lnci:volume num="243"/>
				    <lnci:page num="141"/>
				  </lnci:caseref>
				  <lnci:caseref ID="I493DDGK0K1MND13R0000400">
				    <lnci:reporter normpubcode="630" value="N.W.2d"/>
				    <lnci:ldi jumppage="762" kw="1572_626_762*.762" page="762" pagesuffix="*" reporter="1572" volume="626"/>
				    <lnci:volume num="626"/>
				    <lnci:page num="762"/>
				  </lnci:caseref>
				  <lnci:caseref ID="I493DDGK0K1MND2540000400" exclude="1" generated="1">
				    <lnci:reporter normpubcode="4135" value="Wisc. LEXIS"/>
				    <lnci:volume num="2001"/>
				    <lnci:page num="381"/>
				  </lnci:caseref>
				</lnci:case>
				<lnci:metadata>
				  <lnci:precedent>
				    <lnci:editletter ID="I493DDGK0K1MND2BH0000400" appliedby="machine" comment="Cited in dissenting opinion at" letter="j"/>
				  </lnci:precedent>
				</lnci:metadata>
				<lnci:content>
				  <linktemplate:linktemplate rel="http://services.lexisnexis.com/shared/linkrelations/CITE-REF" href="/shared/document/cases/urn:contentItem:434B-YPP0-0039-43S1-00000-00" type="application/xhtml+xml" domain="services" xmlns:linktemplate="services.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/linktemplate/1/">
				    <request xmlns="">
				      <parameters>
					<parameter style="query" name="CITE-REF" fixed="#23642#2#2001#000046#"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="cfi:contentclasscode" fixed="21"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="cfi:kw-fallback-substring" fixed="#23642#2#2001#"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="cfi:normcite" fixed="2001 WI 46"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="spanid" fixed="I56N5HD52N1R360V20000400"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="contentcomponentid" fixed="10983"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="priceplan" fixed="subscriptions"/>
				      </parameters>
				      <linktext> <emph typestyle="un" xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">State v. Perkins</emph>, 2001 WI 46, 243 Wis. 2d 141, 626 N.W.2d 762</linktext>
				    </request>
				  </linktemplate:linktemplate>
				</lnci:content>
			      </lnci:cite>
			      <rfc:anchorheadnote anchorheadnotetoken="I4F247V40K1MND23K0000400" seqnum="5"/>
			      <rfc:anchorheadnote anchorheadnotetoken="I4F247V40K1MND23M0000400" seqnum="14"/>
			    </rfc:anchorcite>.</text>
			</p>
		      </bodytext>
		    </footnote></rfc:reasonforciting></text>
	      </p>
	      <p xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">
		<ref:anchor id="para_155" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		<text><ref:page num="P135" page-scheme="3481" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> On the basis of these cases, which are, in my opinion, substantially similar to the case at bar, I question the majority opinion's excluding the jury from decision-making regarding guilt in the present case. Here we have a statute prohibiting the carrying of a concealed weapon. The court has read in a constitutional limitation. The majority opinion appears to turn our precedent on its head when it permits a<ref:page num="106" page-scheme="7490" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> court, not the jury, to reach substantive conclusions about the merits of a defendant's constitutional defense to a charge of carrying a concealed weapon when reasonable people might disagree. It seems to me that the majority opinion reverses well-established law when it concludes that a defendant must persuade a court as a matter of law that his defense is meritorious before his defense is presented to the jury. Under the majority opinion, when reasonable people could differ about the availability of <ref:page num="513" page-scheme="3491" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> the defense on the basis of the facts presented, a court is able to bar a defendant's defense.</text>
	      </p>
	      <p xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">
		<ref:anchor id="para_156" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		<text><ref:page num="P136" page-scheme="3481" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> A court may direct only an acquittal as a matter of law. Indeed, this court determines in the present case not just that the defendant was entitled to raise a constitutional defense in the present case but that he prevails in his defense as a matter of law. The majority opinion concludes that the defendant's conviction was unconstitutional and must be reversed unless the State can prove that the defendant carried a concealed weapon for an unlawful purpose. <footnote>
		    <ref:anchor id="fn_fnote81" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		    <label alt-content="n81">81</label>
		    <bodytext>
		      <p>
			<ref:anchor id="fnpara_119" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			<text>Majority op., P84.</text>
		      </p>
		    </bodytext>
		  </footnote></text>
	      </p>
	      <p xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">
		<ref:anchor id="para_157" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		<text><ref:page num="107" page-scheme="7490" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> <ref:page num="P137" page-scheme="3481" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> Second, assuming for the sake of argument that these two questions are properly questions of law for the court, it is unclear why the remaining question of lawful purpose is left to the jury. <footnote>
		    <ref:anchor id="fn_fnote82" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		    <label alt-content="n82">82</label>
		    <bodytext>
		      <p>
			<ref:anchor id="fnpara_120" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			<text>It is also unclear what it means to have a lawful purpose. The majority opinion explains that "carrying a concealed weapon for an unlawful purpose means carrying a concealed weapon in furtherance of the commission of a crime. Majority op., P77. What if there are two purposes for a person to conceal his weapon, one criminal and the other "for security"? What if the purpose is lawful but some other fact makes the concealment unlawful, such as the fact that the weapon carrier is an ex-felon?</text>
		      </p>
		    </bodytext>
		  </footnote> The majority opinion concludes that whether a defendant has an unlawful purpose for bearing a concealed weapon is a question of fact because "it may involve a state of mind for which competing evidence is necessary." <footnote>
		    <ref:anchor id="fn_fnote83" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		    <label alt-content="n83">83</label>
		    <bodytext>
		      <p>
			<ref:anchor id="fnpara_121" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			<text>Majority op., P76.</text>
		      </p>
		    </bodytext>
		  </footnote> Will there not be competing evidence going to the defendant's interest in concealing the weapon, the State's interest <ref:page num="514" page-scheme="3491" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> in enforcing the statute, <footnote>
		    <ref:anchor id="fn_fnote84" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		    <label alt-content="n84">84</label>
		    <bodytext>
		      <p>
			<ref:anchor id="fnpara_122" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			<text>The majority opinion never addresses whether the State's interests in enforcing the statute are established conclusively by this opinion or will vary from case to case.</text>
		      </p>
		    </bodytext>
		  </footnote> or whether concealment was the only reasonable means under the circumstances to carry the gun? I recognize that a person's state of mind is typically a factual determination, but so is reasonableness. The majority opinion does not explain why lawful purpose (question three) is for the jury but not whether there is a reasonable alternative to concealing the weapon (question two). <footnote>
		    <ref:anchor id="fn_fnote85" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		    <label alt-content="n85">85</label>
		    <bodytext>
		      <p>
			<ref:anchor id="fnpara_123" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			<text>Justice <globalentity:entity role="urn:contentType:judge" xmlns:globalentity="urn:x-lexisnexis:content:identified-entities:global:1">
			    <globalentity:content>Bablitch</globalentity:content>
			    <globalentity:entityReference role="urn:contentType:judge" guid:guid="urn:entity:jud-100041936" xmlns:guid="urn:x-lexisnexis:content:guid:global:1"/>
			  </globalentity:entity>'s concurrence analogizes the circuit court's role under the majority opinion's framework to the circuit court's role in determining constitutional facts under a <lnci:cite ID="I494C77C0K1MND1610000400" loadable="1" normcite="U.S. CONST. AMEND. 4" normprotocol="lexstat" ri.key="44041460001" status="valid" xmlns:lnci="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/citations/1/">
			    <lnci:constitution>
			      <lnci:constinfo>
				<lnci:hier>
				  <lnci:hierlev label="catchword" num="amend.">
				    <lnci:hierlev label="number" num="4"/>
				  </lnci:hierlev>
				</lnci:hier>
			      </lnci:constinfo>
			      <lnci:constref normcite="amend._4">
				<lnci:standardname normpubcode="7492" value="U.S. Const."/>
			      </lnci:constref>
			    </lnci:constitution>
			    <lnci:metadata>
			      <lnci:precedent>
				<lnci:editletter ID="I494C77C0K1MND1SR0000400" appliedby="machine" comment="Cited in dissenting opinion at" letter="j"/>
			      </lnci:precedent>
			    </lnci:metadata>
			    <lnci:content popname="1">
			      <linktemplate:linktemplate rel="http://services.lexisnexis.com/shared/linkrelations/CITE-REF" href="/shared/contentstore/statutes-legislation" type="application/xhtml+xml" domain="services" xmlns:linktemplate="services.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/linktemplate/1/">
				<request xmlns="">
				  <parameters>
				    <parameter style="query" name="CITE-REF" fixed="#7492#207#        4 #"/>
				    <parameter style="query" name="cfi:contentclasscode" fixed="38"/>
				    <parameter style="query" name="cfi:normcite" fixed="U.S. Const. AMEND. 4"/>
				    <parameter style="query" name="spanid" fixed="I56N5HD52N1R360V50000400"/>
				    <parameter style="query" name="filters" fixed=""/>
				  </parameters>
				  <linktext>Fourth Amendment</linktext>
				</request>
			      </linktemplate:linktemplate>
			    </lnci:content>
			  </lnci:cite> case. Justice <globalentity:entity role="urn:contentType:judge" xmlns:globalentity="urn:x-lexisnexis:content:identified-entities:global:1">
			    <globalentity:content>Bablitch</globalentity:content>
			    <globalentity:entityReference role="urn:contentType:judge" guid:guid="urn:entity:jud-100041936" xmlns:guid="urn:x-lexisnexis:content:guid:global:1"/>
			  </globalentity:entity>'s concurrence, P96. In the <lnci:cite ID="I494C77C0K1MND1620000400" loadable="1" normcite="U.S. CONST. AMEND. 4" normprotocol="lexstat" ri.key="44041460001" status="valid" xmlns:lnci="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/citations/1/">
			    <lnci:constitution>
			      <lnci:constinfo>
				<lnci:hier>
				  <lnci:hierlev label="catchword" num="amend.">
				    <lnci:hierlev label="number" num="4"/>
				  </lnci:hierlev>
				</lnci:hier>
			      </lnci:constinfo>
			      <lnci:constref normcite="amend._4">
				<lnci:standardname normpubcode="7492" value="U.S. Const."/>
			      </lnci:constref>
			    </lnci:constitution>
			    <lnci:metadata>
			      <lnci:precedent>
				<lnci:editletter ID="I494C77C0K1MND1SS0000400" appliedby="machine" comment="Cited in dissenting opinion at" letter="j"/>
			      </lnci:precedent>
			    </lnci:metadata>
			    <lnci:content>
			      <linktemplate:linktemplate rel="http://services.lexisnexis.com/shared/linkrelations/CITE-REF" href="/shared/contentstore/statutes-legislation" type="application/xhtml+xml" domain="services" xmlns:linktemplate="services.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/linktemplate/1/">
				<request xmlns="">
				  <parameters>
				    <parameter style="query" name="CITE-REF" fixed="#7492#207#        4 #"/>
				    <parameter style="query" name="cfi:contentclasscode" fixed="38"/>
				    <parameter style="query" name="cfi:normcite" fixed="U.S. Const. AMEND. 4"/>
				    <parameter style="query" name="spanid" fixed="I56N5HD52N1R360V60000400"/>
				    <parameter style="query" name="filters" fixed=""/>
				  </parameters>
				  <linktext>Fourth Amendment</linktext>
				</request>
			      </linktemplate:linktemplate>
			    </lnci:content>
			  </lnci:cite> context, however, as the concurrence admits, all questions regarding reasonableness are for the court.</text>
		      </p>
		    </bodytext>
		  </footnote></text>
	      </p>
	      <p xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">
		<ref:anchor id="para_158" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		<text><ref:page num="825" page-scheme="4922" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> <ref:page num="P138" page-scheme="3481" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> As an aside, I am puzzled about where the majority finds the requirement in the constitutional amendment that the purpose be lawful if the individual satisfies the circuit court that he had the weapon for security purposes. The majority opinion reads the constitutional amendment as requiring a person to carry the concealed weapon for security <emph typestyle="un">and</emph> for a lawful purpose. <rfc:reasonforciting rfctoken="I4F246TY0K1MND3X50000400" xmlns:rfc="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/legal/reason-for-citing/1/"><ref:anchor id="I4F246TY0K1MND3X50000400" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>In so doing, the majority opinion is using the catchall in the constitution, "and any other lawful purpose" to restrict the word "security" preceding<ref:page num="109" page-scheme="7490" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> it. This requirement of "lawful purpose" seems to unduly restrict the constitutional amendment's application contrary to its terms. "There is no purpose for the presence of [the catchall phrase] except to expand the list of potential qualifying" purposes. <footnote>
		      <ref:anchor id="fn_fnote86" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		      <label alt-content="n86">86</label>
		      <bodytext>
			<p>
			  <ref:anchor id="fnpara_124" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			  <text><rfc:anchorcite lni="490Y-FGM0-0039-4413-00000-00" rfctokenref="I4F246TY0K1MND3X50000400" status="valid">
			      <ref:anchor id="I4F246TY0K1MND3X40000400" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			      <lnci:cite ID="I493DDGK0K1MND13X0000400" normprotocol="lexsee" ri.key="31788482" status="valid" xmlns:lnci="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/citations/1/">
				<lnci:case>
				  <lnci:caseinfo>
				    <lnci:casename>
				      <lnci:party1 name="State"/>
				      <lnci:text txt="v."/>
				      <lnci:party2 name="Peters"/>
				    </lnci:casename>
				  </lnci:caseinfo>
				  <lnci:caseref ID="I493DDGK0K1MND13Y0000400">
				    <lnci:reporter normpubcode="23642" value="WI"/>
				    <lnci:ldi jumppage="88" kw="1327_2003_88*.88" page="88" pagesuffix="*" reporter="1327" volume="2003"/>
				    <lnci:volume num="2003"/>
				    <lnci:page num="88"/>
				    <lnci:pinpoint num="P23"/>
				  </lnci:caseref>
				  <lnci:caseref ID="I493DDGK0K1MND1430000400">
				    <lnci:reporter normpubcode="111" value="Wis. 2d"/>
				    <lnci:ldi jumppage="475" kw="2005_263_475*.475" page="475" pagesuffix="*" reporter="2005" volume="263"/>
				    <lnci:volume num="263"/>
				    <lnci:page num="475"/>
				  </lnci:caseref>
				  <lnci:caseref ID="I493DDGK0K1MND1450000400">
				    <lnci:reporter normpubcode="630" value="N.W.2d"/>
				    <lnci:ldi jumppage="171" kw="1572_665_171*.171" page="171" pagesuffix="*" reporter="1572" volume="665"/>
				    <lnci:volume num="665"/>
				    <lnci:page num="171"/>
				  </lnci:caseref>
				  <lnci:caseref ID="I493DDGK0K1MND2550000400" exclude="1" generated="1">
				    <lnci:reporter normpubcode="4135" value="Wisc. LEXIS"/>
				    <lnci:volume num="2003"/>
				    <lnci:page num="461"/>
				  </lnci:caseref>
				  <lnci:caseref ID="I4JVTG4Y0K1MNJ4WY0000400" exclude="1" generated="1">
				    <lnci:reporter normpubcode="2166" value="A.L.R.5th"/>
				    <lnci:volume num="125"/>
				    <lnci:page num="775"/>
				  </lnci:caseref>
				</lnci:case>
				<lnci:metadata>
				  <lnci:precedent>
				    <lnci:editletter ID="I493DDGK0K1MND2BJ0000400" appliedby="machine" comment="Cited in dissenting opinion at" letter="j"/>
				  </lnci:precedent>
				</lnci:metadata>
				<lnci:content>
				  <linktemplate:linktemplate rel="http://services.lexisnexis.com/shared/linkrelations/CITE-REF" href="/shared/document/cases/urn:contentItem:490Y-FGM0-0039-4413-00000-00" type="application/xhtml+xml" domain="services" xmlns:linktemplate="services.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/linktemplate/1/">
				    <request xmlns="">
				      <parameters>
					<parameter style="query" name="CITE-REF" fixed="#23642#2#2003#000088#"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="cfi:anchoridref" fixed="PNUM_23_3481"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="cfi:contentclasscode" fixed="21"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="cfi:kw-fallback-substring" fixed="#23642#2#2003#"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="cfi:normcite" fixed="2003 WI 88"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="cfi:pinpoint" fixed="23"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="spanid" fixed="I56N5HD52N1R360V80000400"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="contentcomponentid" fixed="10983"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="priceplan" fixed="subscriptions"/>
				      </parameters>
				      <linktext> <emph typestyle="un" xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">State v. Peters</emph>, 2003 WI 88, P23, 263 Wis. 2d 475, 665 N.W.2d 171</linktext>
				    </request>
				  </linktemplate:linktemplate>
				</lnci:content>
			      </lnci:cite>
			    </rfc:anchorcite>.</text>
			</p>
		      </bodytext>
		    </footnote></rfc:reasonforciting></text>
	      </p>
	      <p xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">
		<ref:anchor id="para_159" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		<text><ref:page num="515" page-scheme="3491" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> <ref:page num="P139" page-scheme="3481" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> Third, a court's determinations that the defendant's interest in concealing a weapon substantially outweighs the State's interest in enforcing the concealed weapons statute (question one) and that concealment is the only reasonable means under the circumstances to carry a weapon (question two) are necessarily intertwined with a determination that the defendant carried a concealed weapon for a lawful purpose. Thus, when a court determines that a constitutional defense may be raised it effectively nullifies the remaining question that the majority opinion reserves for a jury.</text>
	      </p>
	      <p xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">
		<ref:anchor id="para_160" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		<text><ref:page num="P140" page-scheme="3481" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> In the present case, for example, the court's conclusion that the<ref:page num="110" page-scheme="7490" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> defendant's interest in maintaining a concealed weapon substantially outweighs the State's interest in prohibiting concealed weapons is expressly premised on the fact that the defendant possessed and carried his weapon "for purposes of security." <footnote>
		    <ref:anchor id="fn_fnote87" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		    <label alt-content="n87">87</label>
		    <bodytext>
		      <p>
			<ref:anchor id="fnpara_125" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			<text>Majority op., P67. In the same vein, the majority recites the facts of the case as follows: "As a result of these general and specific concerns for the safety of himself, his family, and his customers, and for the security of his property, [the defendant] kept a handgun under the store's front counter next to the cash register during store hours." Majority op., P9.</text>
		      </p>
		    </bodytext>
		  </footnote> The majority opinion holds: "If the constitutional right to bear arms <emph typestyle="un">for security</emph> is to mean anything, it must, as a general matter, permit a person to possess, carry, and sometimes conceal arms to maintain the security of his private residence or privately operated business, and to safely move and store weapons within these premises." <footnote>
		    <ref:anchor id="fn_fnote88" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		    <label alt-content="n88">88</label>
		    <bodytext>
		      <p>
			<ref:anchor id="fnpara_126" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			<text>Majority op., P68 (emphasis added).</text>
		      </p>
		    </bodytext>
		  </footnote> A jury finding that the defendant carried a concealed weapon for an unlawful purpose plainly contradicts the applicability of this legal conclusion to the present case.</text>
	      </p>
	      <p xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">
		<ref:anchor id="para_161" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		<text><ref:page num="516" page-scheme="3491" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> III. COMMENTARY</text>
	      </p>
	      <p xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">
		<ref:anchor id="para_162" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		<text><ref:page num="P141" page-scheme="3481" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> The majority opinion suggests that the legislature needs to "clarify the law" on carrying concealed weapons in light of the new constitutional right to keep and bear arms for security, defense, hunting, recreation, and any other lawful purpose. <footnote>
		    <ref:anchor id="fn_fnote89" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		    <label alt-content="n89">89</label>
		    <bodytext>
		      <p>
			<ref:anchor id="fnpara_127" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			<text>Majority op., P85.</text>
		      </p>
		    </bodytext>
		  </footnote> At the same time, it adopts principles of constitutional law for courts to use in determining whether a person has a constitutional defense to a charge of carrying a concealed weapon "until the legislature takes further action." <footnote>
		    <ref:anchor id="fn_fnote90" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		    <label alt-content="n90">90</label>
		    <bodytext>
		      <p>
			<ref:anchor id="fnpara_128" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			<text>Majority op., P89.</text>
		      </p>
		    </bodytext>
		  </footnote></text>
	      </p>
	      <p xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">
		<ref:anchor id="para_163" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		<text><ref:page num="P142" page-scheme="3481" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> In so doing, the majority opinion fails to appreciate two important points.</text>
	      </p>
	      <p xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">
		<ref:anchor id="para_164" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		<text>
		  <ref:page num="P143" page-scheme="3481" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> <rfc:reasonforciting rfctoken="I4F246TY0K1MND3X70000400" xmlns:rfc="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/legal/reason-for-citing/1/"><ref:anchor id="I4F246TY0K1MND3X70000400" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>First, the legislature's intent in the statute to prohibit the carrying of concealed <ref:page num="826" page-scheme="4922" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> weapons in all places is clear. The history of the constitutional amendment is replete with evidence that the amendment was not intended to<ref:page num="112" page-scheme="7490" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> abrogate existing statutory regulation of firearms. As this court acknowledged in <emph typestyle="un">Cole</emph>, the legislative history behind the constitutional amendment granting the right to bear arms in <globalentity:entity role="urn:contentType:geography" xmlns:globalentity="urn:x-lexisnexis:content:identified-entities:global:1">
		      <globalentity:content>Wisconsin</globalentity:content>
		      <globalentity:entityReference role="urn:contentType:geography" guid:guid="urn:entity:geob-102970657" xmlns:guid="urn:x-lexisnexis:content:guid:global:1"/>
		    </globalentity:entity> "clearly suggests that the legislature did not intend to repeal reasonable gun laws such as the CCW statute." <footnote>
		      <ref:anchor id="fn_fnote91" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		      <label alt-content="n91">91</label>
		      <bodytext>
			<p>
			  <ref:anchor id="fnpara_129" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			  <text><rfc:anchorcite lni="4939-4WB0-0039-402S-00000-00" rfctokenref="I4F246TY0K1MND3X70000400" status="valid">
			      <ref:anchor id="I4F246TY0K1MND3X60000400" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			      <lnci:cite ID="I494C77C0K1MND1630000400" anaphref="I493DDGK0K1MND0W20000400" loadable="1" normprotocol="lexsee" status="valid" xmlns:lnci="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/citations/1/">
				<lnci:case>
				  <lnci:caseref ID="I494C77C0K1MND1B50000400" anaphref="I493DDGK0K1MND0W30000400">
				    <lnci:ldi jumppage="112" kw="1327_2003_112*.112" page="112" pagesuffix="*" reporter="1327" volume="2003"/>
				  </lnci:caseref>
				  <lnci:caseref ID="I494C77C0K1MND16H0000400" anaphref="I493DDGK0K1MND0W50000400">
				    <lnci:ldi jumppage="520" kw="2005_264_520*.520" page="520" pagesuffix="*" reporter="2005" volume="264"/>
				  </lnci:caseref>
				  <lnci:caseref ID="I494C77C0K1MND1650000400" anaphref="I493DDGK0K1MND0W70000400">
				    <lnci:ldi jumppage="328" kw="1572_665_328*.328" page="328" pagesuffix="*" reporter="1572" volume="665"/>
				  </lnci:caseref>
				  <lnci:caseref ID="I494C77C0K1MND1640000400" anaphref="I494C77C0K1MND01C0000400"/>
				</lnci:case>
				<lnci:metadata>
				  <lnci:precedent>
				    <lnci:editletter ID="I494C77C0K1MND1ST0000400" appliedby="machine" comment="Cited in dissenting opinion at" letter="j"/>
				  </lnci:precedent>
				</lnci:metadata>
				<lnci:content>
				  <linktemplate:linktemplate rel="http://services.lexisnexis.com/shared/linkrelations/CITE-REF" href="/shared/document/cases/urn:contentItem:4939-4WB0-0039-402S-00000-00" type="application/xhtml+xml" domain="services" xmlns:linktemplate="services.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/linktemplate/1/">
				    <request xmlns="">
				      <parameters>
					<parameter style="query" name="CITE-REF" fixed="#23642#2#2003#000112#"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="cfi:contentclasscode" fixed="21"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="cfi:kw-fallback-substring" fixed="#23642#2#2003#"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="cfi:normcite" fixed="2003 WI 112"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="spanid" fixed="I56N5HD52N1R360VC0000400"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="contentcomponentid" fixed="10983"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="priceplan" fixed="subscriptions"/>
				      </parameters>
				      <linktext> <emph typestyle="un" xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">Cole</emph>, ___ Wis. 2d ___, P39</linktext>
				    </request>
				  </linktemplate:linktemplate>
				</lnci:content>
			      </lnci:cite>
			      <rfc:anchorheadnote anchorheadnotetoken="I4F247V40K1MND23N0000400" seqnum="13"/>
			      <rfc:anchorheadnote anchorheadnotetoken="I4F247V40K1MND23P0000400" seqnum="17"/>
			      <rfc:anchorheadnote anchorheadnotetoken="I4F247V40K1MND23R0000400" seqnum="18"/>
			    </rfc:anchorcite>.</text>
			</p>
		      </bodytext>
		    </footnote></rfc:reasonforciting>
		</text>
	      </p>
	      <p xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">
		<ref:anchor id="para_165" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		<text>
		  <rfc:reasonforciting rfctoken="I4F246TY0K1MND3XG0000400" xmlns:rfc="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/legal/reason-for-citing/1/">
		    <ref:anchor id="I4F246TY0K1MND3XG0000400" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		    <rfc:reasonforciting rfctoken="I4F246TY0K1MND3XJ0000400"><ref:anchor id="I4F246TY0K1MND3XJ0000400" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/><ref:page num="P144" page-scheme="3481" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> The intent of the amendment was to prevent further erosion of the rights of gun owners, referring to local ordinances regulating guns. <footnote>
			<ref:anchor id="fn_fnote92" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			<label alt-content="n92">92</label>
			<bodytext>
			  <p>
			    <ref:anchor id="fnpara_130" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			    <text><rfc:anchorcite lni="4939-4WB0-0039-402S-00000-00" rfctokenref="I4F246TY0K1MND3XG0000400" status="valid">
				<ref:anchor id="I4F246TY0K1MND3XF0000400" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
				<lnci:cite ID="I494C77C0K1MND1CS0000400" anaphref="I493DDGK0K1MND0W20000400" loadable="1" normprotocol="lexsee" status="valid" xmlns:lnci="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/citations/1/">
				  <lnci:case>
				    <lnci:caseref ID="I494C77C0K1MND1GT0000400" anaphref="I493DDGK0K1MND0W30000400">
				      <lnci:ldi jumppage="112" kw="1327_2003_112*.112" page="112" pagesuffix="*" reporter="1327" volume="2003"/>
				    </lnci:caseref>
				    <lnci:caseref ID="I494C77C0K1MND1FW0000400" anaphref="I493DDGK0K1MND0W50000400">
				      <lnci:ldi jumppage="520" kw="2005_264_520*.520" page="520" pagesuffix="*" reporter="2005" volume="264"/>
				    </lnci:caseref>
				    <lnci:caseref ID="I494C77C0K1MND1FD0000400" anaphref="I493DDGK0K1MND0W70000400">
				      <lnci:ldi jumppage="328" kw="1572_665_328*.328" page="328" pagesuffix="*" reporter="1572" volume="665"/>
				    </lnci:caseref>
				    <lnci:caseref ID="I494C77C0K1MND1F40000400" anaphref="I494C77C0K1MND01C0000400"/>
				  </lnci:case>
				  <lnci:metadata>
				    <lnci:precedent>
				      <lnci:editletter ID="I494C77C0K1MND1SV0000400" appliedby="machine" comment="Cited in dissenting opinion at" letter="j"/>
				    </lnci:precedent>
				  </lnci:metadata>
				  <lnci:content>
				    <linktemplate:linktemplate rel="http://services.lexisnexis.com/shared/linkrelations/CITE-REF" href="/shared/document/cases/urn:contentItem:4939-4WB0-0039-402S-00000-00" type="application/xhtml+xml" domain="services" xmlns:linktemplate="services.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/linktemplate/1/">
				      <request xmlns="">
					<parameters>
					  <parameter style="query" name="CITE-REF" fixed="#23642#2#2003#000112#"/>
					  <parameter style="query" name="cfi:contentclasscode" fixed="21"/>
					  <parameter style="query" name="cfi:kw-fallback-substring" fixed="#23642#2#2003#"/>
					  <parameter style="query" name="cfi:normcite" fixed="2003 WI 112"/>
					  <parameter style="query" name="spanid" fixed="I56N5HD52N1R360VD0000400"/>
					  <parameter style="query" name="contentcomponentid" fixed="10983"/>
					  <parameter style="query" name="priceplan" fixed="subscriptions"/>
					</parameters>
					<linktext> <emph typestyle="un" xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">Cole</emph>, ___ Wis. 2d ___, P64</linktext>
				      </request>
				    </linktemplate:linktemplate>
				  </lnci:content>
				</lnci:cite>
				<rfc:anchorheadnote anchorheadnotetoken="I4F247V40K1MND23S0000400" seqnum="19"/>
			      </rfc:anchorcite> (<globalentity:entity role="urn:contentType:judge" xmlns:globalentity="urn:x-lexisnexis:content:identified-entities:global:1">
				<globalentity:content>Prosser</globalentity:content>
				<globalentity:entityReference role="urn:contentType:judge" guid:guid="urn:entity:jud-100024089" xmlns:guid="urn:x-lexisnexis:content:guid:global:1"/>
			      </globalentity:entity>, J., concurring).</text>
			  </p>
			</bodytext>
		      </footnote> In addition, according to a public opinion poll at the time of <ref:page num="517" page-scheme="3491" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> the amendment, almost 80% of Wisconsinites opposed legalizing the carrying of concealed weapons. <footnote>
			<ref:anchor id="fn_fnote93" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			<label alt-content="n93">93</label>
			<bodytext>
			  <p>
			    <ref:anchor id="fnpara_131" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			    <text><rfc:anchorcite lni="4939-4WB0-0039-402S-00000-00" rfctokenref="I4F246TY0K1MND3XJ0000400" status="valid">
				<ref:anchor id="I4F246TY0K1MND3XH0000400" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
				<lnci:cite ID="I494C77C0K1MND1JK0000400" anaphref="I493DDGK0K1MND0W20000400" loadable="1" normprotocol="lexsee" status="valid" xmlns:lnci="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/citations/1/">
				  <lnci:case>
				    <lnci:caseref ID="I494C77C0K1MND1JR0000400" anaphref="I493DDGK0K1MND0W30000400">
				      <lnci:ldi jumppage="112" kw="1327_2003_112*.112" page="112" pagesuffix="*" reporter="1327" volume="2003"/>
				    </lnci:caseref>
				    <lnci:caseref ID="I494C77C0K1MND1JP0000400" anaphref="I493DDGK0K1MND0W50000400">
				      <lnci:ldi jumppage="520" kw="2005_264_520*.520" page="520" pagesuffix="*" reporter="2005" volume="264"/>
				    </lnci:caseref>
				    <lnci:caseref ID="I494C77C0K1MND1JN0000400" anaphref="I493DDGK0K1MND0W70000400">
				      <lnci:ldi jumppage="328" kw="1572_665_328*.328" page="328" pagesuffix="*" reporter="1572" volume="665"/>
				    </lnci:caseref>
				    <lnci:caseref ID="I494C77C0K1MND1JM0000400" anaphref="I494C77C0K1MND01C0000400"/>
				  </lnci:case>
				  <lnci:metadata>
				    <lnci:precedent>
				      <lnci:editletter ID="I494C77C0K1MND1SW0000400" appliedby="machine" comment="Cited in dissenting opinion at" letter="j"/>
				    </lnci:precedent>
				  </lnci:metadata>
				  <lnci:content>
				    <linktemplate:linktemplate rel="http://services.lexisnexis.com/shared/linkrelations/CITE-REF" href="/shared/document/cases/urn:contentItem:4939-4WB0-0039-402S-00000-00" type="application/xhtml+xml" domain="services" xmlns:linktemplate="services.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/linktemplate/1/">
				      <request xmlns="">
					<parameters>
					  <parameter style="query" name="CITE-REF" fixed="#23642#2#2003#000112#"/>
					  <parameter style="query" name="cfi:contentclasscode" fixed="21"/>
					  <parameter style="query" name="cfi:kw-fallback-substring" fixed="#23642#2#2003#"/>
					  <parameter style="query" name="cfi:normcite" fixed="2003 WI 112"/>
					  <parameter style="query" name="spanid" fixed="I56N5HD52N1R360VF0000400"/>
					  <parameter style="query" name="contentcomponentid" fixed="10983"/>
					  <parameter style="query" name="priceplan" fixed="subscriptions"/>
					</parameters>
					<linktext> <emph typestyle="un" xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">Cole</emph>, ___ Wis. 2d ___, P44</linktext>
				      </request>
				    </linktemplate:linktemplate>
				  </lnci:content>
				</lnci:cite>
				<rfc:anchorheadnote anchorheadnotetoken="I4F247V40K1MND23T0000400" seqnum="19"/>
			      </rfc:anchorcite> (citing Jeffrey Monks, <emph typestyle="un">The End of Gun Control or Protection Against Tyranny?: The Impact of the New <globalentity:entity role="urn:contentType:geography" xmlns:globalentity="urn:x-lexisnexis:content:identified-entities:global:1">
				  <globalentity:content>Wisconsin</globalentity:content>
				  <globalentity:entityReference role="urn:contentType:geography" guid:guid="urn:entity:geob-102970657" xmlns:guid="urn:x-lexisnexis:content:guid:global:1"/>
				</globalentity:entity> Constitutional Right To Bear Arms on State Gun Control Laws</emph>, <lnci:cite ID="I493DDGK0K1MND14Y0000400" normprotocol="lexsee" ri.key="26268938" status="valid" xmlns:lnci="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/citations/1/">
				<lnci:lawrev>
				  <lnci:lawrevref ID="I493DDGK0K1MND14X0000400">
				    <lnci:lawrevlocator>
				      <lnci:publicationname normpubcode="490" value="Wis. L. Rev."/>
				      <lnci:ldi jumppage="284" kw="2004_2001_249*.284" page="249" pagesuffix="*" reporter="2004" volume="2001"/>
				      <lnci:volume num="2001"/>
				      <lnci:page num="249"/>
				      <lnci:pinpoint num="284"/>
				    </lnci:lawrevlocator>
				  </lnci:lawrevref>
				</lnci:lawrev>
				<lnci:metadata>
				  <lnci:precedent>
				    <lnci:editletter ID="I493DDGK0K1MND2BK0000400" appliedby="machine" comment="Cited in dissenting opinion at" letter="j"/>
				  </lnci:precedent>
				</lnci:metadata>
				<lnci:content>
				  <linktemplate:linktemplate rel="http://services.lexisnexis.com/shared/linkrelations/CITE-REF" href="/shared/document/analytical-materials/urn:contentItem:42YD-9NG0-00CW-H0X7-00000-00" type="application/xhtml+xml" domain="services" xmlns:linktemplate="services.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/linktemplate/1/">
				    <request xmlns="">
				      <parameters>
					<parameter style="query" name="CITE-REF" fixed="#490#2#2001#000249#"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="cfi:anchoridref" fixed="PAGE_284_8490"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="cfi:contentclasscode" fixed="3"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="cfi:kw-fallback-substring" fixed="#490#2#2001#"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="cfi:normcite" fixed="2001 Wis. L. Rev. 249"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="cfi:pinpoint" fixed="284"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="spanid" fixed="I56N5HD52N1R360VH0000400"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="contentcomponentid" fixed="7368"/>
					<parameter style="query" name="priceplan" fixed="subscriptions"/>
				      </parameters>
				      <linktext> 2001 Wis. L. Rev. 249, 284</linktext>
				    </request>
				  </linktemplate:linktemplate>
				</lnci:content>
			      </lnci:cite>).</text>
			  </p>
			</bodytext>
		      </footnote></rfc:reasonforciting>
		  </rfc:reasonforciting>
		</text>
	      </p>
	      <p xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">
		<ref:anchor id="para_166" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		<text><ref:page num="113" page-scheme="7490" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> <ref:page num="P145" page-scheme="3481" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> Second, the majority opinion has erected constitutional roadblocks to any further action the legislature might take to determine public policy on concealing firearms and other weapons. The constitutional right to bear arms in <globalentity:entity role="urn:contentType:geography" xmlns:globalentity="urn:x-lexisnexis:content:identified-entities:global:1">
		    <globalentity:content>Wisconsin</globalentity:content>
		    <globalentity:entityReference role="urn:contentType:geography" guid:guid="urn:entity:geob-102970657" xmlns:guid="urn:x-lexisnexis:content:guid:global:1"/>
		  </globalentity:entity> now includes a right not only for all owners of privately owned and operated businesses and persons in their private residences to carry concealed weapons for purposes of security, but for many others as well. The majority not only concludes that for the right to bear arms to mean anything it must mean that a person can conceal arms to "maintain the security of his private residence or privately operated business," <footnote>
		    <ref:anchor id="fn_fnote94" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		    <label alt-content="n94">94</label>
		    <bodytext>
		      <p>
			<ref:anchor id="fnpara_132" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			<text>Majority op., P68. Despite its attempts to limit the present holding to the defendant's precise circumstances, the language in the majority opinion is much broader. For example, the majority opinion concludes, "If the State prosecutes a storeowner for having a concealed weapon within easy reach, it is strongly discouraging the use of firearms for security and is practically nullifying the right to do so." Majority op., P74. This language is hardly limited to the facts of this case.</text>
		      </p>
		    </bodytext>
		  </footnote> but also that the constitutional right to bear arms in <globalentity:entity role="urn:contentType:geography" xmlns:globalentity="urn:x-lexisnexis:content:identified-entities:global:1">
		    <globalentity:content>Wisconsin</globalentity:content>
		    <globalentity:entityReference role="urn:contentType:geography" guid:guid="urn:entity:geob-102970657" xmlns:guid="urn:x-lexisnexis:content:guid:global:1"/>
		  </globalentity:entity> further protects the right of any other person to carry a concealed weapon if a <emph typestyle="un">court</emph> determines that the person's interest in carrying a concealed weapon "substantially outweighs" the State's interest in enforcing the concealed <ref:page num="518" page-scheme="3491" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> weapons statute. <footnote>
		    <ref:anchor id="fn_fnote95" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		    <label alt-content="n95">95</label>
		    <bodytext>
		      <p>
			<ref:anchor id="fnpara_133" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			<text>The two questions the majority opinion establishes for determining whether a constitutional defense is available are broad sweeping and potentially apply to countless individuals under any number of circumstances.</text>
		      </p>
		      <p>
			<ref:anchor id="fnpara_134" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			<text>For example, an owner of a privately operated business caught carrying a concealed weapon while walking to deposit the store's earnings in a bank can certainly argue that he is exercising his right to keep and bear arms under circumstances in which the need to exercise the right is substantial and that concealment, while walking to and upon entering the bank, is the only reasonable means for exercising the right to bear arms under the circumstances. So too can a store manager in charge for an absentee owner argue that she is exercising her right to keep and bear arms under circumstances in which the need to exercise the right is substantial and that concealment is the only reasonable means for exercising the right. Indeed, what is to stop any person from claiming this right in his or her workplace?</text>
		      </p>
		      <p>
			<ref:anchor id="fnpara_135" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			<text>Similarly, anyone who must walk home from a bus stop every night after work through a high crime neighborhood can surely argue that his or her need to exercise the right to bear arms is high, concealment is necessary, and that his or her interests in self-protection substantially outweigh the State's interest in regulating concealed weapons. </text>
		      </p>
		    </bodytext>
		  </footnote> The number of individuals who can fit under the umbrella is large.</text>
	      </p>
	      <p xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">
		<ref:anchor id="para_167" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		<text><ref:page num="115" page-scheme="7490" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> <ref:page num="827" page-scheme="4922" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> <ref:page num="P146" page-scheme="3481" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> More importantly, when any court concludes that an individual is exempted from the prohibition on carrying a concealed weapon under this "substantially outweighs" test, the court is determining that the constitution demands the exception. The legislature may not undo the court's determination absent another constitutional amendment.</text>
	      </p>
	      <p xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">
		<ref:anchor id="para_168" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		<text><ref:page num="P147" page-scheme="3481" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> The majority opinion concludes, "We happily concede that the legislature is better able than this court to determine public policy on firearms and other <ref:page num="519" page-scheme="3491" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> weapons." <footnote>
		    <ref:anchor id="fn_fnote96" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		    <label alt-content="n96">96</label>
		    <bodytext>
		      <p>
			<ref:anchor id="fnpara_136" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
			<text>Majority op., P85.</text>
		      </p>
		    </bodytext>
		  </footnote> Unfortunately, the majority's recognition of its inferior ability did not dissuade it from reading two exceptions into the carrying concealed weapons statute and setting forth criteria for reading additional exceptions into the statute, effectively blocking the legislature from determining public policy concerning concealed weapons.</text>
	      </p>
	      <p xmlns="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/base/1/">
		<ref:anchor id="para_169" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/>
		<text><ref:page num="P148" page-scheme="3481" page-scheme-type="reporter-series-code" xmlns:ref="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/shared/reference/1/"/> For the foregoing reasons, I dissent.  </text>
	      </p>
	    </dissents>
	  </DocumentBody>
	</DOCUMENT>
      </courtcase:courtcase>
    </wfiml:doc>
  </wfiml:content>

support.headline: Namespace prefix bindings missing in some fragmented documents
support.supportDescription: Namespace bindings at the fragment root of fragmented documents can be missing with certain patterns of namespace binding usage. Documents affected can still be queried, but may fail to serialize correctly.

customerImpact.title: Significant business impact with no reasonable workaround

changeHistory.comment: In terms of timing, Lexis has informed us that the release activities that need a fix for this issue will begin around 1/11/13. That means they'll need to begin certifying whatever binary we give them before that - likely early December. In the case we can't hold 6.0-2 and 6.0-3 will not come out in time, they'll likely need a hotfix.

Frank, did you try and simplify this case?  When you say it is missing its namespace prefix, do you mean the namespace is wrong, or that some prefix binding is missing?  Or is this purely a serialization issue?
Danny - both the customer and I tried simplified examples and were unable to reproduce the behavior. It looks like a serialization issue to me, but readily admit that I'm not sure.

I can reproduce this. The XML document has stored the correct namespace for the document, as can be seen if you run the following XQuery:

declare namespace wfiml = "http://services.lexisnexis.com/shared/xmlschema/workfolderitem/2";
doc("/documents/prod.xml")//wfiml:doc

I think this is simply a bug in serialization of the resulting document, so probably not of such a high importance.

Customer context below. While it's true this sort of works, it doesn't really. Ultimately, we are pushing Lexis into strange workarounds and making them suspicious of their data during downstream processing.

In terms of current state - they don't have any kind of a workaround at this time, other than hoping they don't have to do the xqsync operation that discovered the bug again anytime soon. In the event they do have to do that or any other operation affected by this bug, we're not in a position to avoid being characterized as a primary blocker to their go-live in January.

Hey Frank,



From what I can see, the document in this state “works” just fine for us, by virtue of the fact that the <doc> element itself is not actually pulled out of the database. Its child node is what is typically pulled out, so as long as our query can find the <doc> element, we’re good.



However, this is only the first step in the series of steps that led us to discover this bug. The typical scenario for us, where this *does* cause problems is where we copy data (using XQSync) from one database to another, and then back. In that second XQSync step, we find that the <doc> element truly does lose its namespace … even in the index. At that point, a query will NOT find <wfiml:doc> but will only find <doc>.



I have discussed our strategy for the 1/19 release regarding data moves and data migration (we have a strategy in place for running our migration scripts for each release that involves XQSync) with the team handling that. As long as the data is “correct”, and as you have pointed out it is, we should be okay. Our process will not involve two stages of XQSync … it only involves one. My concern, however, is that we are setting ourselves up for potential failure down the road with our next release … when we go through this process once again.



So, the “display” bug isn’t as urgent, and I think we’re okay for our 1/19 release without a fix identified. As we continue to have customer needs to copy their data around, we will have to be aware of this potential gotcha and check the final data. It’s easy enough to replace <doc> with <wfiml:doc> in any munged documents that we find when we’re done, now that we’re aware of the problem.



-Bob

This bug has been around since at least b4_0. It happens with documents that have namespace prefixes go out of scope before reaching a fragment root - in those cases the in-scope namespaces aren't copied to the sub-fragment correctly. You can see this by listing the namespace nodes of the fragment root, ie:

declare namespace wfiml = "http://services.lexisnexis.com/shared/xmlschema/workfolderitem/2";
doc("/documents/prod.xml")//wfiml:doc/namespace::*

This is a problem with ingest - that is, documents loaded before this bug fix will still be broken after the bug fix. The document will need to be re-loaded after the bug fix to see correct behaviour.
bug:20078 Correctly copy in-scope namespaces to sub-fragments of documents
bug:20078 Correctly copy in-scope namespaces to sub-fragments of documents
bug:20279 Correctly copy in-scope namespaces to sub-fragments of documents

Verified on build 6.0-2.1.20121214.x86_64.rpm. Like John has mentioned, the document already loaded before upgrade from 6.0-2 did not have the namespace prefix, but when I reloaded the document, the namespace prefix was present for the <doc> element.
